    • Open Source License Type
    • Model Supply Chain Risk
  • Unmanaged Model (Hugging Face):
    • Model Supply Chain Risk
    • Open Source License Type

To learn more, see Viewing the AI Inventory Details.

See image.

The following additional filters are available for AI Tools & Packages:

  • Access Type
  • Supply Chain Risks
  • License Type

See image.

Model Safety Evaluation Results

The Model Safety Evaluation Results chart visually represents an overall risk score for managed AI models. The safety evaluation details include a risk score for each category. The model assessment results are currently limited to AWS and Azure models.

See image.

To learn more, see Viewing the AI Inventory Details.


Risk Assessment for Open-Source Models

The Risk Assessment Results chart for the open-source model visually represents the overall risk score for the Hugging Face model repository. The assessment results are expandable, and you can drill down to review the risk factors.

See image.

To learn more, see Viewing the AI Inventory Details.

Risk Assessment for Packages

The Package Risk Assessment Results chart visually represents an overall risk score for AI packages in the cloud accounts or those associated with open-source AI models. The score helps quantify the security risks and vulnerabilities. The risk assessment results are expandable, and you can drill down to review the risk factors.

See image.

To learn more, see Viewing the AI Inventory Details.

item.title: Enhancement to the Incidents Page
item.description:
On the Incidents page in the Data Protection integration, the User Groups column is added to the incident table. The User Groups column displays the user groups that the end user is a member of in your organization.

In addition, when you export incidents, the User Groups column appears in the incident export file, and in the Filters window, the User Groups attribute is added as a filter option.

See image.

To learn more, see Managing Incidents and Using Incident Filters in Workflow Automation.

item.title: Manager Software Updates
item.description:
A recommended update was released that includes updated App Connector and ZPA Private Service Edge RPM packages for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.x and 9.x, and Private Cloud Controller and Network Connector RPM packages for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.x.

You can download the Manager software for App Connectors, ZPA Private Service Edges, Private Cloud Controllers, or Network Connectors from our repository. The Manager software version is 25.50.4.

To learn more, see Understanding the Manager Software.

item.title: Support for Quarantine File to Desired Location for File Sharing Apps
item.description:
The support for quarantining files in a desired location has been extended to all file sharing apps, including Box, Dropbox, Confluence, ShareFile, and Smartsheet. This feature was already available for Google Drive, OneDrive, and SharePoint apps. You can specify a quarantine location for files violating DLP policy rules at the time of onboarding the tenant.

On the Edit DLP Rule window, a new action called Admin Quarantine is available for all tenants with a defined quarantine location.

See image.

To learn more, see About Data at Rest Scanning DLP, Configuring the Data at Rest Scanning DLP Policy with Content Inspection, and Configuring the Data at Rest Scanning DLP Policy without Content Inspection.

item.title: Support for Number of Collaborators for File Sharing Apps in DLP
item.description:
The SaaS Security Data at Rest Scanning Data Loss Prevention (DLP) policy supports the number of internal and external collaborators as scoping criteria for all file sharing applications, including Box, Dropbox, Confluence, ShareFile, and Smartsheet. Administrators can monitor file sharing among collaborators by applying the scope to a number of internal and external collaborators.

See image.

To learn more, see Configuring the Data At Rest Scanning DLP Policy and About Data at Rest Scanning DLP.

item.title: Support for Adjustable Polling Intervals
item.description:
When scheduling a scan for SaaS applications tenants (Policy > Scan Configuration > Add Scan Schedule), you can also configure the polling interval based on how often you want the system to scan the application.

See image.

To learn more, see Configuring SaaS Security Scan Schedules.

item.title: Pattern Requirements for Custom DLP Dictionaries
item.description:
For custom Data Loss Prevention (DLP) dictionaries that use patterns with lookaround constructs (also known as zero-length assertions), the Zscaler service now enforces the following restrictions:

  • You must select Match Any Patterns and Any Phrases as the Match Type.
  • You must configure at least one phrase.

To learn more, see Adding Custom DLP Dictionaries.

item.title: Logs for Email Received and Sent Time
item.description:
The following enhancements are available for Insights and NSS Feeds in the ZIA Admin Portal to record the time Zscaler either received or sent an email response.

Insights Logs

New columns Zscaler Sent Time and Zscaler Received Time are added to Email DLP Insights Logs. The Scan Time field is enhanced to reflect the duration of time (milliseconds) from when Zscaler receives an email until the Data Loss Prevention (DLP) policy evaluation is complete.

See image.

To learn more, see Email DLP Insights Logs: Columns.

NSS Feeds

The fields %s{zs_rcv_time} and %s{zs_sent_time} can be added to the Feed Output Format when configuring NSS or Cloud NSS feeds for Email DLP logs. The %llu{scan_time} field is enhanced to reflect the duration of time (milliseconds) from when Zscaler receives an email until the DLP policy evaluation is complete.

To learn more, see NSS Feed Output Format: Email DLP Logs.

item.title: Granular Control for Atlassian AI Application
item.description:
You can allow or block the use of embedded AI applications on Atlassian sites and enable or disable Zscaler to store the generative AI prompts entered in these embedded AI applications per cloud app control rule. As part of this feature, the following fields appear in the Add/Edit Productivity and CRM Tools Rule window only for the Atlassian application:

  • Embedded AI
  • Embedded AI Prompts

See image.

To learn more, see Adding a Productivity & CRM Tools Rule for Cloud App Control.

Web Insights Logs

An Application Activity, Embedded AI, is added to the Web Insights Logs for Atlassian applications only.

See image.

To learn more, see Web Insights Logs: Filters.

item.title: Gen AI Prompt Obfuscation
item.description:
Generative AI (Gen AI) prompts that are displayed in the Web Insights Logs can be obfuscated when adding admin roles.

See image.

To learn more, see About the Gen AI Security Report.

item.title: Enhancement to Virtual Service Edge for Microsoft Azure
item.description:
Virtual Service Edge for Microsoft Azure supports 64 GB of RAM and 3 antivirus (AV) engines per Virtual Service Edge. This allows you to scan large files and maintain Virtual Service Edge performance. You can deploy them either in standalone or cluster mode.

To learn more, see Configuring Virtual Service Edge for Microsoft Azure.

item.title: Enhancement to Virtual Service Edge Clusters for VMware ESXi
item.description:
Virtual Service Edge clusters for VMware ESXi support 64 GB of RAM and three antivirus (AV) engines per Virtual Service Edge. This allows you to scan large files and maintain the performance of the Virtual Service Edges. You can deploy them either in standalone or cluster mode.

To learn more, see Configuring Virtual Service Edge Clusters.

item.title: Enhancement to URL Filtering Policy Page
item.description:
On the URL Filtering Policy page (Policy > URL & Cloud App Control > URL Filtering Policy), the URL Filtering rules are paginated with up to 100 rules displayed per page.

See image.

You can filter and search for URL Filtering rules based on the following categories:

  • Rule Label
  • Rule Name
  • Rule Order
  • Description
  • Action
  • Location
  • Location Group
  • Department
  • Group
  • User
  • Device
  • Device Group
  • Source IP Group
  • URL Categories
  • HTTP Header Profile

See image.

To learn more, see About URL Filtering.

Updates to the Rule Labels and URL Filtering Policy endpoint categories

You can retrieve a list of rule labels based on the specified rule type using the GET /ruleLabels/ruleType/{ruleType} endpoint and retrieve the count of URL Filtering rules using the GET urlFilteringRules/count endpoint.

Two new query parameters, page and pageSize are available for the GET /urlFilteringRules endpoint. When you do not specify the page and pageSize query parameters, the default values are used. To learn more, see Fetching URL Filtering Rules Using Pagination and Search Filters.

To learn more about each endpoint, see the API Reference and API Rate Limit Summary.

item.title: Enhanced Logging of Collaborator Group Members
item.description:
This enhancement allows you to view logs for individual members within a collaborator group. As part of the update, the following changes are available in the ZIA Admin Portal:

SaaS Security Insights Logs and SaaS Security Assets with Incidents

When an individual file is shared with a group, you can view logs for individual members of a group who are either internal collaborators or external collaborators, depending upon the type of domain they belong to in the SaaS Security Insights Logs page and the Assets Report: Assets with Incidents page (Analytics > SaaS Security > Assets > click an application or tenant).

To learn more, see About SaaS Security Insights Logs and Understanding the Assets Report: Assets with Incidents.

SaaS Security Data at Rest Scanning DLP Actions

For file sharing applications, the DLP actions Remove Internal Collaborators, Remove External Collaborators, and Remove External Collaborators and Shareable Link also remove internal and external collaborator groups along with all individual internal and external collaborators. To remove an individual collaborator from an external group, you can use the Remove External Collaborators action on the Remediation page to manually remove the collaborator.

To learn more, see Configuring the Data at Rest Scanning DLP Policy with Content Inspection and Configuring the Data at Rest Scanning DLP Policy without Content Inspection.

item.title: Deprecation of SSPM Policies for Microsoft 365
item.description:
The following policies are deprecated for Microsoft 365 in both SaaS Security Posture Management (SSPM) Essentials and Advanced SSPM:

  • Set Automated Notifications for New and Trending Cloud Applications in Our Organization
  • Set Automated Notification for New OAuth Applications Connected to Your Corporate Environment

To learn more, see Viewing and Managing the Supported SSPM Policies and What Is Advanced Posture Management?

item.title: Zero Trust Branch 8.0.8P1
item.description:
Resolved Issues

The following issues were addressed:

  • Resolves an issue where deleting a Virtual Routing and Forwarding (VRF) configuration from the Zero Trust Branch Admin Portal did not remove the corresponding interface binding.
  • Resolves an issue where DHCP Option 43 did not support hexadecimal values, preventing correct configuration of devices that require hex-encoded option data.
  • Resolves an issue where DNS proxy regex was case sensitive, causing domain-matching failures.
  • Resolves an issue where configuring VLAN or VRF on GE interfaces could fail due to automatic IPv6 link-local address assignment.
  • Resolves an issue where ebond interfaces could not be configured using the Airgap terminal interface, preventing ebond from being used as a primary WAN interface.
  • Resolves an issue where DNS policy did not allow underscore (_) characters in domain objects, preventing configuration of SRV records.

item.title: Ionix Connector Available
item.description:
The Ionix connector enables organizations to retrieve critical data from two streams: Assets and Findings. The connector supports retrieving detailed metadata, including asset IDs, types, statuses, and vulnerabilities. For the Findings stream, the connector retrieves CVE-level details and associated remediation actions, and supports incremental data synchronization.

To learn more, see Configuring the Ionix Connector.

item.title: Endor Labs Connector Available
item.description:
The Endor Labs connector allows organizations to retrieve findings from specified namespaces in the Endor Labs platform, including vulnerabilities using the REST API, as well as Software Composition Analysis (SCA) findings, container-related findings, secrets-related findings, and Static Application Security Testing (SAST) findings using the Query API. The connector retrieves detailed metadata like severity, timestamps, and remediation actions, with the Query API streams supporting data retrieval from a namespace and its child namespaces.

To learn more, see Configuring the Endor Labs Connector.

item.title: Sandboxing Password-Protected PDF Files for Isolation
item.description:
Zscaler Isolation now supports password-protected PDF files to be sandboxed for Zscaler Internet Access (ZIA). If ZIA Sandbox determines that the file is safe, users can download the original PDF. If ZIA Sandbox determines that the file is malicious, users cannot download the original PDF to their local device, and Zscaler stores the password for the duration of the isolated session. If the PDF can be rendered within the isolated browser, users can download the sanitized version of the PDF.

After the PDF is downloaded into the Isolation container, it opens on the user's device automatically, and they are prompted for the file password. Users are allowed unlimited incorrect password attempts.

To learn more, see About Sandbox Integration with Isolation and Transferring and Viewing Files in Isolation.

item.title: Enhancements to Data Protection Features
item.description:
The following are enhancements to the Data Protection features in Workflow Automation:

Protocol Enhancement

A few enhancements were made for incident protocol. These enhancements are:

  • On the Incidents page, the Protocol column is added to the Incidents table for incidents of Source DLP type Inline.

    See image.

In addition, when you export incidents, the Protocol column appears in the export file, and in the Filters window, the Protocol field is added as a filter option.

See image.

To learn more, see Managing Incidents and Using Incident Filters in Workflow Automation.

  • On the Incident Group Mapping page and the Workflow Mapping page, the Protocol property is added for incidents of Source DLP type Inline. You can map incident groups and workflows to this property.

    See image.

To learn more, see Managing Incident Group Mappings and Managing Workflow Mappings.

Enhancement to the Incidents Page

On the Incidents page, each incident in the incident table shows all the engines, rules, and dictionaries it matched. For dictionaries, the number of times the incident matched a specific dictionary is shown in brackets. In addition, the column titles are changed for these attributes.

See image.

To learn more, see Managing Incidents.

item.title: Saved Views in Widgets View Items
item.description:
You can save customized table layouts when viewing widget items, including reordering, adding, or removing columns. Saved views are automatically reusable across all widgets and dashboards that reference the same entity (e.g., Violation Tickets, Assets, or custom entities), increasing consistency and efficiency in data exploration.

See image.

To learn more, see Viewing Items in a Widget Segment.

item.title: Using the Application Map for Microsegmentation
item.description:
The Application Map for Microsegmentation is a visual representation of your network data and how it all works together. The interactive graph provides widgets for resource group, Public Internet, and VPC/VNET data that can aid in policy configuration and general resource maintenance.

See image.

To learn more, see Viewing the Application Map.

item.title: NSS Support for Nutanix
item.description:
Zscalers Nanolog Streaming Service (NSS) supports the configuration and deployment of an NSS virtual machine (VM) on Nutanix.

After deploying an NSS VM, you can stream your organizations Web or Firewall logs from the Zscaler cloud to your security information and event management system.

See image.

To learn more, see NSS Deployment Guide for Nutanix.

item.title: Increased AWS Account IDs in Tenant Profiles
item.description:
You can add up to 512 account IDs per tenant profile for AWS and there can be a maximum of 4,096 account IDs across all profiles.

To learn more, see Adding Tenant Profiles and Ranges & Limitations.

item.title: Update to Amazon GuardDuty Containment Configuration
item.description:
The command to create a role for Amazon GuardDuty containment is updated to create a common role to access the AWS account instead of a tenant-specific role.

See image.

To learn more, see Containment Configuration Guide for Amazon GuardDuty.

item.title: VPC Configuration Updates in AWS Cloud Deception
item.description:
You can deploy RDS and VM image decoys in the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud by specifying the VPC or subnet information.

See image.

Deploying RDS and VM image decoys in the default VPC is no longer supported. Existing decoys that are deployed to the default VPC are not affected and continue to function as expected.

To learn more, see Creating an RDS Decoy in AWS and Creating a VM Image Decoy in AWS.

item.title: Update to Amazon GuardDuty Containment Configuration
item.description:
The command to create a role for Amazon GuardDuty containment is updated to create a common role to access the AWS account instead of a tenant-specific role.

See image.

To learn more, see Containment Configuration Guide for Amazon GuardDuty.

item.title: Terraform Support for Cloud Deception
item.description:
Cloud Deception provides Terraform support for deploying Zscaler Deception components and decoys in the Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Azure clouds. You can download a ready-to-use Terraform package that includes all configuration files required to provision the Deception resources and AWS and Azure decoys. This feature simplifies deployment at scale, improves reproducibility, and aligns cloud deception deployments with existing Infrastructure as Code (IaC) and CI/CD pipelines.

See image.

To learn more, see About Cloud Deception with AWS and About Cloud Deception with Azure.

item.title: RADIUS Decoys
item.description:
RADIUS decoys that mimic real RADIUS servers can be deployed on your internal network via Internal decoys. These decoys respond to authentication attempts, lure the attackers, and divert any threat targeting your RADIUS network.

See image.

To learn more, see Understanding RADIUS Decoys and Deploying a RADIUS Decoy.
